title: Contributing to betaregscale
text: Fork repository create feature branch main. Follow existing code style (snake_case, roxygen2 documentation). Add tests new functionality using testthat. Run devtools::check() ensure 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes. Update documentation devtools::document() needed. Submit pull request clear description changes.

title: Introduction to betaregscale
text: betaregscale package provides maximum-likelihood estimation beta regression models responses derived bounded rating scales. Common examples include pain intensity scales (NRS-11, NRS-21, NRS-101), Likert-type scales, product quality ratings, instrument whose response can mapped open interval (0,1)(0, 1). key idea discrete score recorded bounded scale carries measurement uncertainty inherent instrument. instance, pain score y=6y = 6 0‚Äì10 NRS exact value rather represents range: rescaling (0,1)(0, 1), observation treated interval-censored [0.55,0.65][0.55, 0.65]. package uses beta distribution model data, building complete likelihood supports mixed censoring types within dataset.

title: Introduction to betaregscale
code: # Development version from GitHub: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("evandeilton/betaregscale") library(betaregscale)

title: Introduction to betaregscale
text: complete likelihood (Lopes, 2024, Eq. 2.24) supports four censoring types, automatically classified check_response(): f(‚ãÖ)f(\cdot) F(‚ãÖ)F(\cdot) beta density CDF, [li,ui][l_i, u_i] interval endpoints, (ai,bi)(a_i, b_i) beta shape parameters derived Œºi\mu_i œïi\phi_i via chosen reparameterization.

title: Introduction to betaregscale
text: Scale observations mapped (0,1)(0, 1) uncertainty intervals controlled type argument: "m" (midpoint): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt‚àí0.5/K,yt+0.5/K][y_t - 0.5/K,\; y_t + 0.5/K] "l" (left-aligned): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt,yt+1/K][y_t,\; y_t + 1/K] "r" (right-aligned): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt‚àí1/K,yt][y_t - 1/K,\; y_t] KK number scale categories (ncuts). delta column shows y=0y = 0 left-censored (Œ¥=1\delta = 1), y=10y = 10 right-censored (Œ¥=2\delta = 2), interior values interval-censored (Œ¥=3\delta = 3).

title: Introduction to betaregscale
text: practice, analysts may want supply censoring indicators interval endpoints rather relying automatic classification check_response(). bs_prepare() function provides flexible, validated bridge raw analyst data betaregscale(). supports four input modes:

text: Data processed bs_prepare() automatically detected betaregscale() ‚Äî internal check_response() step skipped:

title: Introduction to betaregscale
text: simulate 200 observations beta regression model fixed dispersion, two covariates, logit link mean. default midpoint interval type means observation centered interval. example, score 67 0‚Äì100 scale yields yt=0.67y_t = 0.67 interval [0.665,0.675][0.665, 0.675].

title: Introduction to betaregscale
text: package supports three reparameterizations beta distribution, controlled repar argument: Direct (repar = 0): Shape parameters =Œºa = \mu b=œïb = \phi used directly. rarely used practice. Precision (repar = 1, Ferrari & Cribari-Neto, 2004): mean Œº‚àà(0,1)\mu \(0,1) precision œï>0\phi > 0 yield =Œºœïa = \mu\phi b=(1‚àíŒº)œïb = (1-\mu)\phi. Higher œï\phi means less variability. Mean‚Äìvariance (repar = 2): mean Œº‚àà(0,1)\mu \(0,1) dispersion œï‚àà(0,1)\phi \(0,1) yield =Œº(1‚àíœï)/œïa = \mu(1-\phi)/\phi b=(1‚àíŒº)(1‚àíœï)/œïb = (1-\mu)(1-\phi)/\phi. œï\phi acts coefficient variation: smaller œï\phi means less variability.
code: # Precision parameterization: mu = 0.5, phi = 10 (high precision) beta_reparam(mu = 0.5, phi = 10, repar = 1) #>   shape1 shape2 #> 1      5      5  # Mean-variance parameterization: mu = 0.5, phi = 0.1 (low dispersion) beta_reparam(mu = 0.5, phi = 0.1, repar = 2) #>   shape1 shape2 #> 1    4.5    4.5

what: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
text: Beta Regression Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes betaregscale package provides maximum-likelihood estimation beta regression models responses derived bounded rating scales (e.g., NRS-11, NRS-21, NRS-101, Likert scales). Observations treated interval-censored (0, 1) scale--unit transformation, likelihood built beta CDF evaluated interval endpoints. package designed situations recorded score carries measurement uncertainty inherent instrument. example, pain score 6 (0-10) NRS scale interpreted lying interval [5.5, 6.5] rescaling (0, 1). complete likelihood (Lopes, 2024, Eq. 2.24) supports mixed censoring types: uncensored, left-censored, right-censored, interval-censored within dataset.

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
text: Mixed censoring support: complete likelihood handles four censoring types simultaneously: exact observations (Œ¥=0\delta=0), left-censored (Œ¥=1\delta=1), right-censored (Œ¥=2\delta=2), interval-censored (Œ¥=3\delta=3). Fixed variable dispersion: model scalar œï\phi let depend covariates via second linear predictor (y ~ x1 + x2 | z1). High-performance C++ backend: log-likelihood analytical gradient compiled via Rcpp/RcppArmadillo fast, numerically stable estimation. Flexible link functions: logit, probit, cauchit, cloglog mean; logit, log, identity, sqrt, inverse, others dispersion. Three reparameterizations: direct (0), Ferrari‚ÄìCribari-Neto precision (1), mean‚Äìvariance (2). betareg-style S3 interface: print, summary, coef, vcov, logLik, AIC, BIC, nobs, formula, model.matrix, fitted, residuals, predict, confint, plot methods. coef() vcov() methods accept model = c("full", "mean", "precision"). Diagnostic plots: six residual diagnostic panels base R ggplot2 backends, including half-normal envelope plot. Censoring summary: censoring_summary() provides visual tabular summaries censoring structure. Simulation toolkit: betaregscale_simulate() betaregscale_simulate_z() Monte Carlo studies.

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
code: # Development version from GitHub: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("evandeilton/betaregscale")

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
code: library(betaregscale)  # Simulate interval-censored data from a fixed-dispersion model set.seed(42) n <- 200 dat <- data.frame(x1 = rnorm(n), x2 = rnorm(n)) sim <- betaregscale_simulate(   formula = ~ x1 + x2, data = dat,   beta = c(0.3, -0.6, 0.4), phi = 1/10,   link = "logit", link_phi = "logit",   ncuts = 100, type = "m", repar = 2 ) head(sim)  # Fit the model fit <- betaregscale(y ~ x1 + x2, data = sim, repar = 2) summary(fit)

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
code: # Simulate data with covariate-dependent dispersion set.seed(2222) n <- 200 dat <- data.frame(   x1 = rnorm(n), x2 = rnorm(n),   z1 = rnorm(n), z2 = rnorm(n) ) sim_z <- betaregscale_simulate_z(   formula_x = ~ x1 + x2, formula_z = ~ z1,   data = dat,   beta = c(0.2, -0.6, 0.2),   zeta = c(0.2, -0.8),   link = "logit", link_phi = "logit",   ncuts = 100, type = "m", repar = 2 )  # Fit variable-dispersion model (pipe notation) fit_z <- betaregscale(y ~ x1 + x2 | z1, data = sim_z, repar = 2) summary(fit_z)

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
text: complete log-likelihood mixed censoring (Lopes, 2024, Eq. 2.24) combines four observation types: ‚Ñì(ùõâ)=‚àë:Œ¥i=0logf(yi)+‚àë:Œ¥i=1logF(ui)+‚àë:Œ¥i=2log[1‚àíF(li)]+‚àë:Œ¥i=3log[F(ui)‚àíF(li)] \ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \sum_{:\,\delta_i=0} \log f(y_i) + \sum_{:\,\delta_i=1} \log F(u_i) + \sum_{:\,\delta_i=2} \log [1 - F(l_i)] + \sum_{:\,\delta_i=3} \log [F(u_i) - F(l_i)] f(‚ãÖ)f(\cdot) F(‚ãÖ)F(\cdot) beta density CDF, [li,ui][l_i, u_i] interval endpoints, Œ¥i\delta_i indicates censoring type.

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
text: Scale observations mapped (0, 1) uncertainty intervals whose width depends type parameter: "m" (midpoint): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt‚àí0.5/K,yt+0.5/K][y_t - 0.5/K,\; y_t + 0.5/K] "l" (left): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt,yt+1/K][y_t,\; y_t + 1/K] "r" (right): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt‚àí1/K,yt][y_t - 1/K,\; y_t] KK number scale categories (ncuts).

text: Scalar: total log-likelihood.

title: Log-likelihood for fixed-dispersion beta interval regression ‚Äî betaregscale_loglik
text: complete likelihood observation \(\) censoring indicator \(\delta_i\) (Lopes, 2024, Eq. 2.24): \(\delta = 0\) (uncensored) \(\ell_i = \log f(y_i | a_i, b_i)\) \(\delta = 1\) (left-censored) \(\ell_i = \log F(u_i | a_i, b_i)\) \(\delta = 2\) (right-censored) \(\ell_i = \log(1 - F(l_i | a_i, b_i))\) \(\delta = 3\) (interval-censored) \(\ell_i = \log(F(u_i | a_i, b_i) - F(l_i | a_i, b_i))\) \(a_i\) \(b_i\) beta shape parameters derived mean \(\mu_i = g^{-1}(x_i'\beta)\) scalar dispersion \(\phi = h^{-1}(\gamma)\) chosen reparameterization.

title: Log-likelihood for fixed-dispersion beta interval regression ‚Äî betaregscale_loglik
code: set.seed(42) n <- 100 dat <- data.frame(x1 = rnorm(n), x2 = rnorm(n)) sim <- betaregscale_simulate(   formula = ~ x1 + x2, data = dat,   beta = c(0, 0.5, -0.2), phi = 1 / 5 ) betaregscale_loglik(   param = c(0, 0.5, -0.2, 1 / 5),   formula = y ~ x1 + x2, data = sim ) #> [1] -417.4957

title: Simulate data from a fixed-dispersion beta interval model ‚Äî betaregscale_simulate
text: formula One-sided formula specifying mean model predictors (e.g., ~ x1 + x2). data Data frame containing predictor variables. beta Numeric vector regression coefficients (length must equal number columns design matrix, including intercept). phi Scalar dispersion parameter (link scale). link Mean link function (default "logit"). Supported: "logit", "probit", "cloglog", "cauchit", "log". link_phi Dispersion link function (default "logit"). ncuts Integer: number scale categories \(K\) (default 100). type Deprecated. Interval type: "m", "l", "r". Use bs_prepare control interval geometry instead. lim Numeric: half-width \(h\) uncertainty region (default 0.5). repar Integer: reparameterization scheme (default 2). 0 = direct \((, b)\), 1 = precision/Ferrari \((\mu, \phi = + b)\), 2 = mean-variance/Bayer \((\mu, \phi = 1/(+ b + 1))\). delta Integer NULL.  NULL (default),   censoring determined automatically   check_response. integer {0, 1, 2, 3}, simulated   observations forced censoring type.  actual   simulated values preserved observation-specific   endpoints reflect underlying covariate-driven variation.   See Details.

title: Simulate data from a fixed-dispersion beta interval model ‚Äî betaregscale_simulate
text: data.frame \(n\) rows columns:   left, right, yt, y, delta,   plus predictor columns data.   delta != NULL, data frame carries attribute   "bs_prepared" = TRUE.

title: Simulate data from a fixed-dispersion beta interval model ‚Äî betaregscale_simulate
text: Data generation process: design matrix \(X\) built formula     data. linear predictor \(\eta = X \beta\), mean     \(\mu = g^{-1}(\eta)\) \(g\) link     function. scalar dispersion     \(\phi = h^{-1}(\texttt{phi})\) \(h\)     dispersion link. Beta shape parameters \((, b)\) derived     \((\mu, \phi)\) via chosen reparameterization scheme. Raw values \(y^*_i \sim \text{Beta}(a_i, b_i)\)     drawn \((0, 1)\). raw values transformed response matrix     .build_simulated_response() (see ). Role delta argument: delta = NULL (default), raw values rounded scale grid (\(y_{\text{grid}} = \text{round}(y^* \times K)\)) passed check_response automatic classification: \(y = 0 \\delta = 1\), \(y = K \\delta = 2\), otherwise \(\delta = 3\).  resulting dataset natural mix censoring types driven simulated values. delta integer \(\{0, 1, 2, 3\}\), observations forced censoring type, actual simulated \(y^*\) values preserved grid observation retains covariate-driven variation.  Specifically: delta = 0 (exact) continuous \(y^*\) values     used directly \((0, 1)\);     \(l_i = u_i = y_t = y^*_i\). delta = 1 (left-censored) grid values     \(y_{\text{grid}} = \text{round}(y^* K)\) kept.     check_response() called forced     delta = rep(1, n), producing:     \(l_i = \epsilon\),     \(u_i = (y_{\text{grid}} + h) / K\) non-boundary,     \(u_i = h / K\) \(y_{\text{grid}} = 0\). delta = 2 (right-censored) logic:     \(u_i = 1 - \epsilon\),     \(l_i = (y_{\text{grid}} - h) / K\) non-boundary,     \(l_i = (K - h) / K\) \(y_{\text{grid}} = K\). delta = 3 (interval-censored) Grid values     clamped \([1, K-1]\) (avoiding boundaries)     check_response() called forced     delta = rep(3, n). Attribute "bs_prepared": delta != NULL, returned data frame carries attribute "bs_prepared" = TRUE.  signals .extract_response() (thus betaregscale, betaregscale_loglik, etc.) pre-computed columns left, right, yt, delta used directly, bypassing automatic classification check_response.  Without attribute, fitting functions re-classify response y column alone, ignore forced delta produce incorrect censoring indicators (e.g., observation \(y = 50\) forced \(\delta = 2\) reclassified \(\delta = 3\) boundary rules). delta = NULL, attribute set, default pipeline applies.

title: Simulate data from a fixed-dispersion beta interval model ‚Äî betaregscale_simulate
code: set.seed(42) n <- 200 dat <- data.frame(x1 = rnorm(n), x2 = rnorm(n)) sim <- betaregscale_simulate(   formula = ~ x1 + x2, data = dat,   beta = c(0.2, -0.5, 0.3), phi = 1 / 5,   link = "logit", link_phi = "logit" ) head(sim) #>      left right      yt  y delta         x1         x2 #> 1 0.17500 0.185 0.18000 18     3  1.3709584 -2.0009292 #> 2 0.69500 0.705 0.70000 70     3 -0.5646982  0.3337772 #> 3 0.07500 0.085 0.08000  8     3  0.3631284  1.1713251 #> 4 0.61500 0.625 0.62000 62     3  0.6328626  2.0595392 #> 5 0.01500 0.025 0.02000  2     3  0.4042683 -1.3768616 #> 6 0.00001 0.005 0.00001  0     1 -0.1061245 -1.1508556  # Force all observations to be interval-censored sim3 <- betaregscale_simulate(   formula = ~ x1 + x2, data = dat,   beta = c(0.2, -0.5, 0.3), phi = 1 / 5,   delta = 3 ) table(sim3$delta) #>  #>   3  #> 200   # Force right-censored: y values vary, all delta = 2 sim2 <- betaregscale_simulate(   formula = ~ x1 + x2, data = dat,   beta = c(0.2, -0.5, 0.3), phi = 1 / 5,   delta = 2 ) head(sim2[, c("left", "right", "y", "delta")]) #>    left   right   y delta #> 1 0.005 0.99999   1     2 #> 2 0.495 0.99999  50     2 #> 3 0.015 0.99999   2     2 #> 4 0.995 0.99999 100     2 #> 5 0.015 0.99999   2     2 #> 6 0.115 0.99999  12     2 # Note: left varies per observation, right = 1 - eps

what: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
text: Validates transforms raw data format required betaregscale. analyst can supply data several ways: Minimal (Mode 1): score y.     Censoring inferred automatically:     \(y = 0 \\delta = 1\), \(y = K \\delta = 2\),     \(0 < y < K \\delta = 3\),     \(y \(0, 1) \\delta = 0\). Classic (Mode 2): y + explicit     delta. analyst declares censoring type;     interval endpoints computed using actual y     value. Interval (Mode 3): left /    right columns (original scale). Censoring     inferred NA pattern. Full (Mode 4): y, left,     right together. analyst's endpoints     rescaled directly \((0, 1)\). covariate columns preserved unchanged output.

title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
code: bs_prepare(   data,   y = "y",   delta = "delta",   left = "left",   right = "right",   ncuts = 100L,   type = "m",   lim = 0.5 )

title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
text: data data.frame containing response (optionally) covariates. y Character: name score column (default "y"). delta Character: name censoring indicator column (default "delta"). Values must {0, 1, 2, 3}. left Character: name left-endpoint column (default "left"). right Character: name right-endpoint column (default "right"). ncuts Integer: number scale categories (default 100). type Deprecated. Character: interval type interior scores y delta available. "m" = midpoint (default), "l" = left-aligned, "r" = right-aligned. argument removed future version. lim Numeric: half-width uncertainty region (default 0.5). Used constructing intervals y alone.

title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
text: data.frame following columns appended   replaced: left Lower endpoint \((0, 1)\). right Upper endpoint \((0, 1)\). yt Midpoint approximation \((0, 1)\). y Original scale value (preserved reference). delta Censoring indicator: 0 = exact, 1 = left,       2 = right, 3 = interval. Covariate columns preserved.   output carries attributes "bs_prepared" (TRUE),   "ncuts", "type", "lim"   betaregscale can detect prepared data skip   internal check_response call.

title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
text: Priority rule: delta provided (non-NA), takes precedence automatic classification rules. delta NA, function infers censoring type pattern left, right, y: y, left, right present observation, analyst's left/right values used directly (rescaled \(K =\) ncuts) delta set 3 (interval-censored) unless analyst supplied delta explicitly. Endpoint formulas Mode 2 (y + explicit delta): analyst supplies delta explicitly, endpoint computation uses actual y value produce observation-specific bounds.  logic used check_response user-supplied delta vector: Consistency warnings: analyst supplies delta values unusual given y (e.g., \(\delta = 1\) \(y \neq 0\)), function emits warning proceeds.  design Monte Carlo workflows forced delta non-boundary observations intentional. endpoints clamped \([\epsilon, 1 - \epsilon]\) \(\epsilon = 10^{-5}\).

title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
code: # --- Mode 1: y only (automatic classification, like check_response) --- d1 <- data.frame(y = c(0, 3, 5, 7, 10), x1 = rnorm(5)) bs_prepare(d1, ncuts = 10) #> bs_prepare: n = 5 | exact = 0, left = 1, right = 1, interval = 3 #>      left   right      yt  y delta         x1 #> 1 0.00001 0.05000 0.00001  0     1  0.5029463 #> 2 0.25000 0.35000 0.30000  3     3  0.9688992 #> 3 0.45000 0.55000 0.50000  5     3 -0.8757371 #> 4 0.65000 0.75000 0.70000  7     3 -2.1360245 #> 5 0.95000 0.99999 0.99999 10     2 -1.5228276  # --- Mode 2: y + explicit delta --- d2 <- data.frame(   y     = c(50, 0, 99, 50),   delta = c(0, 1, 2, 3),   x1    = rnorm(4) ) bs_prepare(d2, ncuts = 100) #> Warning: Observation(s) 3: delta = 2 (right-censored) but y != 100. #> bs_prepare: n = 4 | exact = 1, left = 1, right = 1, interval = 1 #>      left   right      yt  y delta           x1 #> 1 0.50000 0.50000 0.50000 50     0 -1.113118208 #> 2 0.00001 0.00500 0.00001  0     1  1.240983896 #> 3 0.98500 0.99999 0.99000 99     2  0.003481935 #> 4 0.49500 0.50500 0.50000 50     3 -1.237794586  # --- Mode 3: left/right with NA patterns --- d3 <- data.frame(   left  = c(NA, 20, 30, NA),   right = c(5, NA, 45, NA),   y     = c(NA, NA, NA, 50),   x1    = rnorm(4) ) bs_prepare(d3, ncuts = 100) #> bs_prepare: n = 4 | exact = 1, left = 1, right = 1, interval = 1 #>    left   right    yt  y delta         x1 #> 1 1e-05 0.05000 0.025 NA     1  0.5556991 #> 2 2e-01 0.99999 0.600 NA     2 -2.1831493 #> 3 3e-01 0.45000 0.375 NA     3 -0.2470245 #> 4 5e-01 0.50000 0.500 50     0  1.1128569  # --- Mode 4: y + left + right (analyst-supplied intervals) --- d4 <- data.frame(   y     = c(50, 75),   left  = c(48, 73),   right = c(52, 77),   x1    = rnorm(2) ) bs_prepare(d4, ncuts = 100) #> bs_prepare: n = 2 | exact = 0, left = 0, right = 0, interval = 2 #>   left right   yt  y delta         x1 #> 1 0.48  0.52 0.50 50     3 -0.3416732 #> 2 0.73  0.77 0.75 75     3  1.3054383  # --- End-to-end workflow --- # \donttest{ set.seed(42) n <- 200 dat <- data.frame(x1 = rnorm(n), x2 = rnorm(n)) sim <- betaregscale_simulate(   formula = ~ x1 + x2, data = dat,   beta = c(0.2, -0.5, 0.3), phi = 1 / 5 ) prep <- bs_prepare(sim, ncuts = 100) #> bs_prepare: n = 200 | exact = 0, left = 18, right = 21, interval = 161 fit <- betaregscale(y ~ x1 + x2, data = prep) #> Warning: The 'type' argument of betaregscale_fit() is deprecated and will be removed in a future version. Use bs_prepare() to control interval geometry. summary(fit) #>  #> Call: #> betaregscale(formula = y ~ x1 + x2, data = prep) #>  #> Quantile residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -3.0625 -0.5896  0.2555  0.6723  1.5528  #>  #> Coefficients (mean model with logit link): #>             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)     #> (Intercept) -5.15677    0.08757 -58.886  < 2e-16 *** #> x1          -0.38266    0.06216  -6.156 7.45e-10 *** #> x2           0.12275    0.06556   1.872   0.0612 .   #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‚Äò***‚Äô 0.001 ‚Äò**‚Äô 0.01 ‚Äò*‚Äô 0.05 ‚Äò.‚Äô 0.1 ‚Äò ‚Äô 1 #>  #> Phi coefficients (precision model with logit link): #>       Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)     #> (phi)  -4.8810     0.1352  -36.11   <2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‚Äò***‚Äô 0.001 ‚Äò**‚Äô 0.01 ‚Äò*‚Äô 0.05 ‚Äò.‚Äô 0.1 ‚Äò ‚Äô 1 #> --- #> Log-likelihood: -896.1340 on 4 Df #> Pseudo R-squared: 0.1097  #> Number of iterations: 29 (BFGS)  #> Censoring: 161 interval | 18 left | 21 right  #>  # }

what: Transform and validate a scale-derived response variable ‚Äî check_response
title: Transform and validate a scale-derived response variable ‚Äî check_response
text: Takes discrete (continuous) response scale \(0, 1, \ldots, K\) (\(K =\) ncuts) converts pair interval endpoints open unit interval \((0, 1)\).  observation classified one four censoring types following complete likelihood Lopes (2024, Eq. 2.24): \(\delta = 0\) Uncensored (exact): observation     continuous value already \((0, 1)\).  likelihood     contribution density \(f(y_i | \theta)\).     Endpoints: \(l_i = u_i = y_i\) (\(y_i / K\)     scale). \(\delta = 1\) Left-censored: latent value     upper bound \(u_i\).  contribution     \(F(u_i | \theta)\).     observation scale minimum (\(y = 0\)),     upper bound \(u_i = \mathrm{lim} / K\).     user forces \(\delta = 1\) non-boundary     observation (\(y \neq 0\)), upper bound     \(u_i = (y + \mathrm{lim}) / K\), preserving observation-     specific variation.  cases \(l_i = \epsilon\). \(\delta = 2\) Right-censored: latent value     lower bound \(l_i\).  contribution     \(1 - F(l_i | \theta)\).     observation scale maximum (\(y = K\)),     lower bound \(l_i = (K - \mathrm{lim}) / K\).     user forces \(\delta = 2\) non-boundary     observation (\(y \neq K\)), lower bound     \(l_i = (y - \mathrm{lim}) / K\), preserving observation-     specific variation.  cases \(u_i = 1 - \epsilon\). \(\delta = 3\) Interval-censored: standard case     scale data.  contribution     \(F(u_i | \theta) - F(l_i | \theta)\).  Endpoints depend     interval type (see Details).

title: Transform and validate a scale-derived response variable ‚Äî check_response
text: y Numeric vector: raw response.  Can either integer scores scale \(\{0, 1, \ldots, K\}\) continuous values already \((0, 1)\). type Deprecated. Character: interval type \(\delta = 3\) observations. "m" = midpoint (default), "l" = left-aligned, "r" = right-aligned. Use bs_prepare control interval geometry instead. ncuts Integer: number scale categories \(K\) (default 100).  Must \(\geq \max(y)\). lim Numeric: half-width \(h\) uncertainty region (default 0.5).  Controls width interval around scale point. delta Integer vector NULL.  NULL   (default), censoring types inferred automatically   boundary rules described . provided, must length y, every   element {0, 1, 2, 3}.  supplied values override   automatic classification per-observation basis,   endpoint formulas adapt non-boundary observations   described table . parameter used internally simulation functions   analyst forces specific censoring type   (e.g., betaregscale_simulate(..., delta = 2)).

title: Transform and validate a scale-derived response variable ‚Äî check_response
text: numeric matrix \(n\) rows 5 columns: left Lower endpoint \(l_i\) \((0, 1)\),     clamped \([\epsilon, 1 - \epsilon]\). right Upper endpoint \(u_i\) \((0, 1)\),     clamped \([\epsilon, 1 - \epsilon]\). yt Midpoint approximation \(y_t\)     starting-value computation (enter likelihood). y Original response value (preserved unchanged). delta Censoring indicator: 0 = exact (density),     1 = left-censored \(F(u)\), 2 = right-censored     \(1 - F(l)\), 3 = interval-censored \(F(u) - F(l)\).

title: Transform and validate a scale-derived response variable ‚Äî check_response
text: Automatic classification (delta = NULL): entire input vector already \((0, 1)\) (.e., values satisfy \(0 < y < 1\)), observations treated uncensored (\(\delta = 0\)). Otherwise, scale (integer) data: \(y = 0\): left-censored (\(\delta = 1\)). \(y = K\): right-censored (\(\delta = 2\)). \(0 < y < K\): interval-censored (\(\delta = 3\)). User-supplied delta (delta vector): delta argument provided, user-supplied censoring indicators override automatic boundary-based rules per-observation basis.  mechanism used betaregscale_simulate analyst forces specific censoring type Monte Carlo studies. endpoint formulas delta value : endpoints clamped \([\epsilon, 1 - \epsilon]\) \(\epsilon = 10^{-5}\) avoid boundary issues beta likelihood. midpoint approximation yt computed : \(y_t = y\) \(y \(0, 1)\) (continuous data). \(y_t = y / K\) \(y\) integer scale. value used exclusively initialization aid starting-value computation enter likelihood. Interaction fitting pipeline: function called internally .extract_response() data carry "bs_prepared" attribute.  data pre-processed bs_prepare simulation forced delta (betaregscale_simulate delta != NULL), pre-computed columns used directly check_response() skipped.

text: Pearson residuals variance formula depends reparameterization stored object$repar: repar = 1 (precision) V = mu(1 - mu) / (1 + phi) repar = 2 (mean-variance) V = mu(1 - mu) * phi weighted sweighted residuals use digamma/trigamma formulation precision parameterization (repar = 1), internal conversion applied repar != 1.

title: betaregscale 2.1.1
text: delta argument simulation functions: betaregscale_simulate() betaregscale_simulate_z() gain delta argument (default NULL) forces simulated observations specific censoring type: 0 (exact), 1 (left), 2 (right), 3 (interval). enables targeted Monte Carlo studies analyst controls censoring structure. delta non-NULL, actual simulated values (y_raw = rbeta(n, , b)) preserved scale grid, forced censoring indicator passed check_response() vector. ensures observation retains covariate-driven variation observation-specific endpoints. returned data frame carries attr(, "bs_prepared") = TRUE betaregscale(), betaregscale_loglik(), fitting functions use pre-computed left, right, yt, delta columns directly, bypassing automatic boundary classification. Without attribute, fitting pipeline re-classify response y column alone, ignore forced delta. delta argument check_response(): accepts integer vector pre-specified censoring indicators, overriding automatic boundary-based classification per-observation basis. endpoint formulas adapt non-boundary observations: distinction boundary non-boundary observations essential: delta = 1 forced non-zero y, upper bound uses actual y value ((y + lim)/K) rather fixed boundary formula (lim/K). preserves information content observation. Observation-specific endpoints bs_prepare(): internal .compute_endpoints() helper now uses adaptive formulas check_response() analyst-forced left/right censoring non-boundary scores. Previously, delta = 1 always produced right = lim/K delta = 2 always produced left = (K - lim)/K, regardless actual y value.

title: betaregscale 2.1.1
text: Simulation forced delta = 1 delta = 2: internal .build_simulated_response() helper previously replaced y values boundary values (y_grid = rep(0, n) delta = 1, y_grid = rep(ncuts, n) delta = 2). produced degenerate data every observation identical endpoints (e.g., left = 0.995, right = 0.99999 delta = 2), destroying covariate-driven variation making regression fitting impossible. fix preserves actual simulated grid values (y_grid = round(y_raw * ncuts)) passes forced delta vector check_response(), computes observation-specific endpoints using actual y values. Missing "bs_prepared" attribute simulation output: delta forced, simulation functions mark output attr(, "bs_prepared") = TRUE. result, betaregscale() re-classify response via check_response(), silently overwriting forced delta automatic boundary rules. attribute now set correctly.

title: betaregscale 2.1.1
text: type parameter ("m", "l", "r") deprecated across functions: betaregscale(), betaregscale_fit(), betaregscale_fit_z(), betaregscale_loglik(), betaregscale_loglik_z(), betaregscale_simulate(), betaregscale_simulate_z(), check_response(), bs_prepare(). Use bs_prepare() control interval geometry instead. parameter still works emits deprecation warning passed explicitly.

title: betaregscale 2.0.1
text: bs_prepare() data preprocessing: new analyst-facing function validates, classifies censoring, rescales raw data model fitting. Supports four flexible input modes: score-, score + explicit delta, interval endpoints NA patterns, analyst-supplied left/right bounds. Prepared data automatically detected betaregscale(). Internal helper .extract_response() enables transparent detection bs_prepare()-processed data across fitting, log-likelihood, starting-value functions. censoring_summary() now also accepts data frames bs_prepare(). New vignette section documenting four data preparation modes.

title: betaregscale 2.0.1
text: Fixed potential row-indexing bug bs_prepare() receives subset data frame non-sequential row names. Output now always sequential row names (1:n).

title: betaregscale 2.0.0
text: Removed dependency bbmle. model fitting now uses stats::optim() directly analytical gradients via C++ backend. betaregscale_bbmle() function removed. cumulative parameter replaced delta indicator vector, supports mixed censoring types within dataset. Parameter dados renamed data across functions. Simulation functions renamed: betaregscale_simula_dados() now betaregscale_simulate(), betaregscale_simula_dados_z() now betaregscale_simulate_z().

title: betaregscale 2.0.0
text: Mixed censoring support: complete likelihood (Eq. 2.24) now handles four censoring types simultaneously: exact (Œ¥=0\delta=0), left-censored (Œ¥=1\delta=1), right-censored (Œ¥=2\delta=2), interval-censored (Œ¥=3\delta=3). C++ backend rewrite: log-likelihood analytical gradient functions rewritten C++ (RcppArmadillo) numerically stable, high-performance evaluation. betareg-style S3 interface: coef() vcov() now accept model = c("full", "mean", "precision") argument. New S3 methods: nobs(), formula(), model.matrix(), confint(), plot(). confint() provides Wald confidence intervals based asymptotic normal approximation (z-test, t-test). plot() method six diagnostic panels (residuals vs indices, Cook‚Äôs distance, residuals vs linear predictor, residuals vs fitted, half-normal envelope, predicted vs observed) base R ggplot2 backends. censoring_summary() function visual tabular summaries censoring structure, base R ggplot2 backends. predict() expanded five types: "response", "link", "precision", "variance", "quantile". Supports newdata fixed variable dispersion models. residuals() supports five types: "response", "pearson", "rqr" (randomized quantile residuals), "weighted", "sweighted". summary() output now shows separate coefficient tables mean precision submodels Wald z-tests.

title: betaregscale 2.0.0
text: Fixed Pearson residual computation correctly dispatch reparameterization type (repar 1 vs repar 2). Fixed predict() newdata variable-dispersion models. Fixed p-values use pnorm() (standard normal) instead pt() (Student-t), consistent Wald inference theory (Eq. 2.34‚Äì2.35).

title: betaregscale 1.1.1
text: Initial public release bbmle-based fitting. Support fixed variable dispersion models. Basic S3 methods: coef, vcov, fitted, residuals, summary, print.
